title: How to Quiet a Cough Naturally

steps.title: Suck on ice chips, hard candy, or lozenges to comfort an irritated throat.
steps.content: Suck on ice chips, hard candy, or lozenges to comfort an irritated throat. Keep a glass of ice chips by your side and suck on a few whenever you need some relief. Popping a lozenge, hard candy, or cough drop can also soothe your throat and quiet a persistent cough when you're out and about. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Lozenges made with real honey may provide additional soothing properties, but most expensive medicine-flavored cough drops aren't any better at providing relief than inexpensive lozenges or hard candies. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can buy lozenges and cough drops at grocery stores and pharmacies. Never give lozenges to children under the age of 4 to prevent choking.

steps.title: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and reduce irritation.
steps.content: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and reduce irritation. Simply drinking some water can help reduce a nagging cough, especially in dry surroundings, because it is soothing as it travels down your throat. Liquids also prevent the lining of your nostrils and throat from drying out and keeps mucus moist so that it's easier for you to get rid of. [5] X Research source Water is the best choice, but unsweetened fruit juices, decaffeinated herbal teas, and sports drinks are fine in moderation. [6] X Research source Avoid caffeinated beverages like coffee, black tea, and soft drinks, as well as alcoholic beverages. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Drink soothing warm beverages like hot tea to quiet a cough.
steps.content: Drink soothing warm beverages like hot tea to quiet a cough. Stick with decaffeinated teas and caffeine-free herbal teas. Simply brew up your favorite kind and enjoy a mug of it as often as you'd like throughout the day. If you aren't usually a tea drinker, you might try out herbal varieties like peppermint, ginger, or chamomile. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Drinking warm soup broths can also provide comfort. [9] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Caffeine is dehydrating and may ultimately worsen your cough. Stirring in a small amount of honey or fresh lemon juice may provide additional soothing properties. They also taste delicious in a warm mug of tea!

steps.title: Avoid cigarettes
steps.content: Avoid cigarettes and other throat irritants to reduce coughing. Exposure to smoke, dust, fumes, and other pollutants can irritate your throat and lungs. Avoid smoking cigarettes, second-hand smoke, and spending time in areas where you’re likely to breathe pollutants. [10] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Chemical cleaning products can irritate your throat and worsen a cough. [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Elevate your head while you sleep to prevent postnasal drip.
steps.content: Elevate your head while you sleep to prevent postnasal drip. Place 1-2 extra pillows under your head so it stays propped up during the night. This upright position prevents mucus from trickling down your throat, which is often the culprit if coughing tends to wake you up during the night.

steps.title: Take a hot shower to moisten your airways.
steps.content: Take a hot shower to moisten your airways. The steam from a hot shower can lubricate your throat and reduce a cough. Jump into a hot shower and breathe in the steam for about 20 minutes. Be sure to take slow, deep breaths. [12] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source If you don't want to get in the water, just close the bathroom door and breathe in the steam that fills the room.

steps.title: Use a cool mist humidifier or vaporizer to add moisture to the air.
steps.content: Use a cool mist humidifier or vaporizer to add moisture to the air. Fill your machine with distilled water and position it at least 3–4 ft (0.91–1.22 m) from your bed. You can run the machine several times per day or during the night while you're sleeping, but avoid constant use. Don't forget to drain and clean your humidifier or vaporizer every day so bacteria doesn't grow inside of it. [13] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Running a humidifier or vaporizer 24/7 encourages mold and mildew growth. Avoid using tap water in your humidifier. The machine will turn minerals in tap water into a white dust and release into the air. Breathing in this dust can cause coughing and breathing problems.

steps.title: Gargle with warm salt water
steps.content: Gargle with warm salt water to relieve a sore throat. Stir 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon (1 to 2 grams) of table salt into 4 to 8 ounces (118 to 236 ml) of warm water. Tilt your head back and gargle with the solution for about 1 minute. Then, spit the salt water out into your sink. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Avoid swallowing salt water. It can make you sick to your stomach. Salt water gargles are safe for anyone over the age of 6.

steps.title: Flush your sinuses and reduce mucus with saline nasal drops.
steps.content: Flush your sinuses and reduce mucus with saline nasal drops. Stand over a sink and angle your head downward. Place the tip of the bottle in 1 nostril and spray. Rotate your head back and allow the solution to drip back out of your nose naturally. Repeat the process for your other nostril. [15] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source > Getting rid of mucus prevents it from going down your throat, which will force you to cough it up. Blow your nose gently to remove any leftover saline solution when you're done. You can buy saline nasal drops over-the-counter at most pharmacies and grocery stores.

steps.title: Irrigate your sinuses with a Neti pot to prevent postnasal drip.
steps.content: Irrigate your sinuses with a Neti pot to prevent postnasal drip. Fill a Neti pot with distilled water and stir saline powder into it until it dissolves. Tilt your head to the side and put the spout of the Neti pot in your upper nostril. Breathe through your mouth and slowly pour the solution into the nostril. The liquid should come out of your lower nostril in 3-4 seconds. Repeat the process in your other nostril. [16] X Trustworthy Source US Food and Drug Administration U.S. government agency responsible for promoting public health Go to source Blow your nose gently when you're done to clear any leftover solution. Clean your Neti pot thoroughly between uses to prevent germs and bacteria from entering your nasal passages the next time you use it. If you must use tap water, be sure to boil it first to kill bacteria and organisms. Let the water cool before using it.

steps.title: See your doctor if your cough doesn’t go away in 3 to 4 weeks.
steps.content: See your doctor if your cough doesn’t go away in 3 to 4 weeks. [17] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source A chronic cough can be caused by many common issues, like allergies, asthma, GERD, or some other underlying illness, [18] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source so it's best to have your doctor evaluate you and formally diagnose the problem. A chest X-ray or lung function test may be recommended. [19] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You may have a bacterial infection, which can be treated with prescription antibiotics. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Visit your doctor immediately if you develop more severe symptoms.
steps.content: Visit your doctor immediately if you develop more severe symptoms. Wheezing, fever, and coughing up thick, greenish-yellow phlegm usually indicate an infection in the chest or lungs. It’s best to see your doctor as soon as possible so you won't prolong your recovery. Antibiotics or some other treatment may be prescribed. Call your doctor if you have the following severe symptoms: [21] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Fever higher than 100 °F (38 °C) Coughing up green or yellow phlegm Wheezing Shortness of breath

steps.title: Get emergency care if you’re having trouble breathing or swallowing.
steps.content: Get emergency care if you’re having trouble breathing or swallowing. If you're struggling to breathe, it's time to go to the ER. Let the ER doctor know how long you’ve had the cough, as well as any other symptoms you’re experiencing. You should seek emergency medical care for the following symptoms: [22] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Choking or vomiting Difficulty breathing or swallowing Bloody or pink-tinged phlegm Chest pain

steps.title: See your doctor immediately if you’re having coughing fits or gasping.
steps.content: See your doctor immediately if you’re having coughing fits or gasping. These symptoms may mean you have a more serious condition, like whooping cough. Ask your doctor for a same-day appointment or go to an urgent care center to make sure you're okay. They can find out what’s causing your cough and offer you the right treatment. [23] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Whooping cough is highly contagious and requires medical treatment, so don't hesitate to see your doctor if you experience these symptoms.
